articles.title: 140,000-year-old skeleton shows earliest interbreeding between humans and Neanderthals
articles.summary: Scientists have uncovered the world s earliest fossil showing both Neanderthal and Homo sapiens features: a five-year-old child from Israel s Skhul Cave dating back 140,000 years. This discovery pushes back the timeline of human interbreeding, proving that Neanderthals and modern humans were already mixing long before Europe s later encounters.
articles.content:
Research team: "This discovery reveals the world's earliest known human fossil showing morphological traits of both of these human groups, which until recently were considered two separate human species. The current study shows that the five-year-old child's skeleton is the result of continuous genetic infiltration from the local -- and older -- Neanderthal population into the Homo sapiens population."

An international study led by researchers from Tel Aviv University and the French National Centre for Scientific Research provides the first scientific evidence that Neanderthals and Homo sapiens had biological and social relations, and even interbred for the first time, in the Land of Israel. The research team found a combination of Neanderthal and Homo sapiens traits in the skeleton of a five-year-old child discovered about 90 years ago in the Skhul Cave on Mount Carmel. The fossil, estimated to be about 140,000 years old, is the earliest human fossil in the world to display morphological features of both of these human groups, which until recently were considered two separate species. The study was led by Prof. Israel Hershkovitz of the Gray Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences at Tel Aviv University and Anne Dambricourt-Malassé of the French National Centre for Scientific Research. The findings of this historic discovery were published in the journal l'Anthropologie.

"Genetic studies over the past decade have shown that these two groups exchanged genes," explains Prof. Hershkovitz. "Even today, 40,000 years after the last Neanderthals disappeared, part of our genome -- 2 to 6 percent -- is of Neanderthal origin. But these gene exchanges took place much later, between 60,000 to 40,000 years ago. Here, we are dealing with a human fossil that is 140,000 years old. In our study, we show that the child's skull, which in its overall shape resembles that of Homo sapiens -- especially in the curvature of the skull vault -- has an intracranial blood supply system, a lower jaw, and an inner ear structure typical of Neanderthals."

For years, Neanderthals were thought to be a group that evolved in Europe, migrating to the Land of Israel only about 70,000 years ago, following the advance of European glaciers. In a groundbreaking 2021 study published in the prestigious journal Science, Prof. Hershkovitz and his colleagues showed that early Neanderthals lived in the Land of Israel as early as 400,000 years ago. This human type, which Prof. Hershkovitz called "Nesher Ramla Homo" (after the archaeological site near the Nesher Ramla factory where it was found), encountered Homo sapiens groups that began leaving Africa about 200,000 years ago -- and, according to the current study's findings, interbred with them. The child from the Skhul Cave is the earliest fossil evidence in the world of the social and biological ties forged between these two populations over thousands of years. The local Neanderthals eventually disappeared when they were absorbed into the Homo sapiens population, much like the later European Neanderthals.

The researchers reached these conclusions after conducting a series of advanced tests on the fossil. First, they scanned the skull and jaw using micro-CT technology at the Shmunis Family Anthropology Institute at Tel Aviv University, creating an accurate three-dimensional model from the scans. This enabled them to perform a complex morphological analysis of the anatomical structures (including non-visible structures such as the inner ear) and compare them to various hominid populations. To study the structure of the blood vessels surrounding the brain, they also created an accurate 3D reconstruction of the inside of the skull.

"The fossil we studied is the earliest known physical evidence of mating between Neanderthals and Homo sapiens," says Prof. Hershkovitz. "In 1998, a skeleton of a child was discovered in Portugal that showed traits of both of these human groups. But that skeleton, nicknamed the 'Lapedo Valley Child,' dates back to 28,000 years ago -- more than 100,000 years after the Skhul child. Traditionally, anthropologists have attributed the fossils discovered in the Skhul Cave, along with fossils from the Qafzeh Cave near Nazareth, to an early group of Homo sapiens. The current study reveals that at least some of the fossils from the Skhul Cave are the result of continuous genetic infiltration from the local -- and older -- Neanderthal population into the Homo sapiens population."
articles.reasoning: The discovery of the earliest known human fossil showing interbreeding between Neanderthals and Homo sapiens provides significant new scientific evidence about human evolution and social interaction. It has broad implications for our understanding of human origins and shared ancestry, which is inspiring and uplifting for society as it highlights deep-rooted biological and social connections among humans.
articles.personality_title: 140,000-year-old child fossil reveals earliest mix of humans and Neanderthals
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long studied Neanderthals and modern humans (Homo sapiens) as separate groups. Neanderthals were thought to have lived mainly in Europe, while early modern humans came from Africa. Previous evidence showed they mixed much later, around 60,000 years ago.

**What happened** – Researchers from Tel Aviv University and France studied a 140,000-year-old skeleton of a five-year-old child found in Israel’s Skhul Cave. This fossil has features of both Neanderthals and modern humans, such as the shape of the skull and inner ear. Using advanced 3D scans and analysis, they found this is the oldest known evidence that these two groups lived together and interbred.

**Impact** – This discovery changes what we know about human history. It shows Neanderthals and modern humans started mixing much earlier than before thought, in the Land of Israel. The child’s skeleton proves they shared genes and social ties long before they met again in Europe. It also helps explain how Neanderthals eventually disappeared by blending into the modern human population.

**What’s next step** – Scientists will continue studying fossils from this region and time period to learn more about how these groups lived and interacted. This could lead to a better understanding of human evolution and how different human groups influenced each other’s development.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The 140,000-year-old child fossil from Israel is the earliest proof that Neanderthals and modern humans lived together and interbred much earlier than previously known.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un enfant fossile vieux de 140 000 ans révèle le premier mélange entre humains et Néandertaliens
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques considéraient longtemps les Néandertaliens et les humains modernes (Homo sapiens) comme deux groupes séparés. Les Néandertaliens vivaient principalement en Europe, tandis que les premiers humains modernes venaient d’Afrique. Les preuves montraient qu’ils se sont mélangés seulement il y a environ 60 000 ans.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de Tel Aviv et de France ont étudié un squelette d’un enfant de cinq ans vieux de 140 000 ans découvert dans la grotte de Skhul en Israël. Ce fossile présente des caractéristiques à la fois des Néandertaliens et des humains modernes, comme la forme du crâne et de l’oreille interne. Grâce à des analyses 3D avancées, ils ont prouvé que c’est la plus ancienne preuve connue que ces deux groupes ont vécu ensemble et se sont croisés.

**Impact** – Cette découverte change notre compréhension de l’histoire humaine. Elle montre que Néandertaliens et humains modernes ont commencé à se mélanger beaucoup plus tôt qu’on ne le pensait, en Israël. Le squelette de l’enfant prouve qu’ils partageaient des gènes et des liens sociaux bien avant leur rencontre en Europe. Cela explique aussi comment les Néandertaliens ont disparu en se fondant dans la population humaine moderne.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont continuer à étudier les fossiles de cette région et période pour mieux comprendre comment ces groupes vivaient et interagissaient. Cela pourrait améliorer notre connaissance de l’évolution humaine et des influences mutuelles entre groupes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le fossile de l’enfant de 140 000 ans en Israël est la plus ancienne preuve que Néandertaliens et humains modernes vivaient ensemble et se croisaient bien plus tôt qu’on ne le croyait.
articles.personality_title_es: Fósil de niño de 140,000 años revela la mezcla más antigua entre humanos y neandertales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos solían pensar que los neandertales y los humanos modernos (Homo sapiens) eran grupos separados. Los neandertales vivían principalmente en Europa, y los humanos modernos venían de África. La evidencia mostraba que se mezclaron mucho después, hace unos 60,000 años.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Tel Aviv y de Francia estudiaron el esqueleto de un niño de cinco años de 140,000 años encontrado en la cueva Skhul en Israel. Este fósil tiene características tanto de neandertales como de humanos modernos, como la forma del cráneo y el oído interno. Usando escaneos 3D avanzados, demostraron que es la evidencia más antigua de que estos dos grupos vivieron juntos y se cruzaron.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento cambia lo que sabemos sobre la historia humana. Muestra que neandertales y humanos modernos comenzaron a mezclarse mucho antes de lo que se pensaba, en la Tierra de Israel. El esqueleto del niño prueba que compartían genes y relaciones sociales mucho antes de encontrarse de nuevo en Europa. También ayuda a explicar cómo desaparecieron los neandertales al mezclarse con los humanos modernos.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos seguirán estudiando fósiles de esta región y época para aprender más sobre cómo vivían e interactuaban estos grupos. Esto podría ayudar a entender mejor la evolución humana y cómo se influyeron mutuamente.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El fósil del niño de 140,000 años de Israel es la prueba más antigua de que neandertales y humanos modernos vivieron juntos y se cruzaron mucho antes de lo que se sabía.

articles.title: Bulgaria is among the strongest supporters of Ukraine’s European integration, said Prime Minister Rosen Zhelyazkov in a conversation with the Ukrainian Prime Minister
articles.summary: The support for Ukraine in the context of the war remains unwavering, assured the Bulgarian Prime Minister.
articles.content:
The support for Ukraine in the context of the war remains unwavering, assured the Bulgarian Prime Minister.

SOFIA/KYIV – Bulgaria is among the strongest and most active supporters of Ukraine’s European integration, based on the principle of its own merits. We are ready to assist Kyiv on the European path by sharing valuable experience in the integration process. This was stated by Prime Minister Rosen Zhelyazkov during a video conference call with Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Svyrydenko, the press service of the Council of Ministers reported.

Prime Minister Zhelyazkov welcomed Ukraine’s strong commitment to key reforms related to the European Union (EU), especially in the context of the current geopolitical security challenges and the ongoing full-scale Russian aggression.

Bulgaria firmly believes that Ukraine’s future is in the EU, and European integration is a guarantee of prosperity for the entire region, noted Zhelyazkov.

Bulgaria supports the decision to open the first negotiation cluster, emphasized Bulgarian Prime Minister Zhelyazkov, highlighting the importance of the Ukrainian action plan regarding national minorities, considering it an indispensable component for opening the first negotiation chapter.

Rosen Zhelyazkov confirmed Bulgaria’s unwavering support for Ukraine in the context of the war. He noted that the Bulgarian government welcomes all efforts to achieve a lasting solution, including through the commitment of the administration of U.S. President Donald Trump to end the full-scale aggression of Russia against Ukraine.

Negotiations should be based on the principles of justice, sovereignty, and security guarantees, ensuring that peace is not just the absence of war, but a foundation for long-term stability, security, and prosperity for Europe and Ukraine, stated Rosen Zhelyazkov.

He emphasized Bulgaria’s readiness to engage in the post-war recovery, reconstruction, and reform process in Ukraine. During the meeting, issues related to regional energy security and transport connectivity were also discussed.

Prime Minister Rosen Zhelyazkov participated on August 19 in a video conference meeting of the heads of state and government of EU member states, where the outcomes of the meeting in Washington regarding Ukraine were discussed. Security guarantees for Ukraine should include sustainable support from both European and Euro-Atlantic partners, stated Zhelyazkov. Bulgaria, together with our EU partners and NATO allies, is ready to contribute to achieving a framework for a just and lasting peace, the Prime Minister further stated. (20.08.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article highlights Bulgaria's strong and active support for Ukraine's European integration amid ongoing conflict, emphasizing commitment to reforms, justice, sovereignty, and long-term peace. This support has broad geopolitical significance and potential positive impact on regional stability, security, and prosperity, with concrete readiness for post-war recovery and reform.
articles.personality_title: Bulgaria stands firm in supporting Ukraine’s path to the European Union

**What happened** – On August 19, Bulgarian Prime Minister Rosen Zhelyazkov spoke by video call with Ukraine’s Prime Minister Yulia Svyrydenko. He said Bulgaria is one of the strongest supporters of Ukraine joining the EU. Bulgaria offered to share its own experience with Ukraine to help with reforms needed for membership. Zhelyazkov also confirmed Bulgaria’s support during the ongoing war and talked about working together on peace, security, and rebuilding after the conflict.

**Impact** – Bulgaria’s support is important because it shows Ukraine is not alone in its efforts to join the EU, even during war. Bulgaria’s offer to help with reforms and reconstruction could speed up Ukraine’s European integration. This support also sends a message that peace and security in the region matter to European countries, which could help bring stability.

**What's next step** – Bulgaria and Ukraine will likely continue working closely on reforms and plans for Ukraine’s EU membership. Bulgaria also plans to help with rebuilding Ukraine after the war ends. Discussions about regional energy and transport connections will continue, helping strengthen ties between Ukraine and Europe.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bulgaria is actively supporting Ukraine’s journey toward EU membership and stands ready to help with reforms, peace efforts, and rebuilding amid ongoing conflict.

articles.title: Commissioner Hansen: EU support should target active and young farmers
articles.summary: Czech farmers do not agree with the new policy, which among other things introduces a cap on subsidies, nor with the amount of the European agricultural budget.
articles.content:
České Budějovice – Support from the future common European agricultural policy should primarily be directed towards active farmers who contribute to food production, not to those who merely own land. This was agreed upon by the European Commissioner for Agriculture Christophe Hansen and the Minister of Agriculture Mark Výborný (KDU-ČSL) during today’s briefing at the agricultural fair Země živitelka. According to Hansen, it is also necessary to support farmers operating in disadvantaged areas as well as young and beginning farmers.

“We must support those who need it the most, who actively contribute to food and commodity production,” said Hansen. Výborný also called for the creation of a stable system that would allow farmers to plan, invest, and adapt to future challenges. “Czechia needs to know the legislation as soon as possible so that we can prepare and avoid any transitional period. We want to be ready for agriculture to be based on stability and to be competitive,” said Výborný.

Czech farmers do not agree with the new policy, which among other things introduces a cap on subsidies, nor with the level of the European agricultural budget. They criticize the abolition of the two-pillar structure, according to which funds are primarily distributed for investments and direct payments linked to area or livestock. “We are concerned about the budget drop in real terms by up to half compared to the current period, as well as the abolition of the two-pillar system, which is based on direct payments and investment subsidies. The European Commission did not take into account the current difficult situation of farmers and food producers, nor the future economic impacts of the proposed relatively radical changes in the existing functioning of the subsidy system, without which European agriculture cannot do without,” said the president of the Agrarian Chamber of the Czech Republic Jan Doležal in response to a question from ČTK.

In response to the criticism, Hansen pointed out that the first proposal for the future agricultural policy and budget will still be discussed, and individual countries should know their budgets within a few weeks. The Commissioner also noted that much of the criticism stems from “misinformation and comparing apples to oranges.” “The proposal provides predictability for farmers so they can reinvest and more young people can return to the sector,” added Hansen.

The merger of pillars is defended by the Commissioner as a greater simplification and efficiency in the disbursement of subsidies. According to him, the new approach respects the diversity of member states and brings a significant number of simplifications that farmers have called for. Hansen and Výborný consider the discussion of the so-called simplification package, which aims to reduce the administrative burden on farmers, as one of the current priorities. The European Commission is also expected to present a second package this autumn, which should address biological alternatives to plant protection products, for example. “It is necessary for the packages to be discussed this year in November so that they can be incorporated into national legislation,” warned Výborný. (August 21)
articles.reasoning: The article discusses a significant policy shift in the EU agricultural support system aimed at prioritizing active, young, and disadvantaged farmers, which could lead to more equitable and sustainable agricultural practices benefiting a broad population. The focus on simplification and support for new farmers has meaningful potential societal impact. Although there is criticism and uncertainty, the policy aims to create stability and inclusivity in farming, which is a positive development with substantial scope.
articles.personality_title: EU plans to support active and young farmers with new agricultural policy
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union is changing how it supports farmers through a new common agricultural policy. This policy affects how financial help is given to farmers across EU countries, including the Czech Republic.

**What happened** – European Commissioner Christophe Hansen and Czech Agriculture Minister Mark Výborný spoke about the new plan at an agricultural fair. They said support should focus on farmers who actively work the land, especially young farmers and those in difficult areas. The policy will combine different types of subsidies to simplify the system. However, some Czech farmers disagree with the changes, especially the limit on subsidies and the reduction of the overall budget.

**Impact** – This new policy aims to help farmers who produce food and need the most support, rather than just landowners. It could make farming more fair and easier to manage by reducing paperwork. Supporting young and starting farmers could bring fresh energy to farming and help secure food production for the future. But some farmers worry about less money and big changes that might be hard to handle.

**What's next step** – The European Commission will continue discussing the policy and budgets. Countries will soon learn how much support they will receive. There will also be efforts to reduce administrative work for farmers and introduce new rules, like safer alternatives to pesticides. These changes are expected to be finalized and included in national laws by the end of the year.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s new agricultural policy focuses on helping active, young, and disadvantaged farmers with simpler support systems to strengthen farming’s future.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’UE prévoit de soutenir les agriculteurs actifs et jeunes avec une nouvelle politique agricole
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne modifie la façon dont elle soutient les agriculteurs grâce à une nouvelle politique agricole commune. Cette politique influence l’aide financière accordée aux agriculteurs dans les pays de l’UE, y compris la République tchèque.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le commissaire européen Christophe Hansen et le ministre tchèque de l’Agriculture Mark Výborný ont présenté ce nouveau plan lors d’un salon agricole. Ils ont déclaré que le soutien devrait être destiné aux agriculteurs qui travaillent activement la terre, en particulier les jeunes et ceux des zones difficiles. La politique va fusionner différents types de subventions pour simplifier le système. Cependant, certains agriculteurs tchèques ne sont pas d’accord avec ces changements, notamment la limitation des aides et la réduction du budget global.

**Impact** – Cette nouvelle politique vise à aider les agriculteurs qui produisent de la nourriture et ont le plus besoin de soutien, plutôt que de simplement aider les propriétaires terriens. Cela pourrait rendre l’agriculture plus juste et plus facile à gérer en réduisant la paperasserie. Soutenir les jeunes agriculteurs peut apporter un nouvel élan et aider à garantir la production alimentaire pour l’avenir. Mais certains agriculteurs craignent une baisse des financements et des changements importants difficiles à gérer.

**Prochaine étape** – La Commission européenne continuera à discuter de la politique et des budgets. Les pays sauront bientôt combien de soutien ils recevront. Des efforts seront faits pour réduire les tâches administratives des agriculteurs et introduire de nouvelles règles, comme des alternatives plus sûres aux pesticides. Ces changements devraient être finalisés et intégrés dans les lois nationales d’ici la fin de l’année.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La nouvelle politique agricole de l’UE vise à aider les agriculteurs actifs, jeunes et en difficulté avec des systèmes de soutien simplifiés pour renforcer l’avenir de l’agriculture.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE planea apoyar a agricultores activos y jóvenes con nueva política agrícola
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea está cambiando la forma en que apoya a los agricultores mediante una nueva política agrícola común. Esta política afecta cómo se brinda ayuda económica a los agricultores en los países de la UE, incluida la República Checa.

**Qué pasó** – El comisario europeo Christophe Hansen y el ministro checo de Agricultura Mark Výborný hablaron sobre el nuevo plan en una feria agrícola. Dijeron que el apoyo debe enfocarse en los agricultores que trabajan activamente la tierra, especialmente jóvenes y aquellos en zonas difíciles. La política combinará diferentes tipos de subsidios para simplificar el sistema. Sin embargo, algunos agricultores checos no están de acuerdo con los cambios, especialmente con el límite a los subsidios y la reducción del presupuesto total.

**Impacto** – Esta nueva política busca ayudar a los agricultores que producen alimentos y necesitan más apoyo, no solo a los dueños de tierras. Podría hacer que la agricultura sea más justa y fácil de manejar al reducir el papeleo. Apoyar a los jóvenes agricultores puede traer energía nueva y ayudar a asegurar la producción de alimentos en el futuro. Pero algunos agricultores temen menos dinero y cambios grandes que pueden ser difíciles de manejar.

**Próximo paso** – La Comisión Europea seguirá discutiendo la política y los presupuestos. Los países pronto sabrán cuánto apoyo recibirán. También habrá esfuerzos para reducir las tareas administrativas para los agricultores e introducir nuevas reglas, como alternativas más seguras a los pesticidas. Se espera que estos cambios se finalicen y se incluyan en las leyes nacionales antes de fin de año.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La nueva política agrícola de la UE se centra en ayudar a agricultores activos, jóvenes y en zonas difíciles con sistemas de apoyo más simples para fortalecer el futuro de la agricultura.
